An SSD is great for speed but they are just a big flash drive that has a life span determined but the quantity of read / writes, so it's better to have an conventional HDD for long term backup. You can get free software to monitor how much life an SD has before failure. For a laptop an external HDD to back up to works well for my. While in my desktop I have both with storage for things not used daily and a partition for scheduled backup of the main SSD.

I would like to add that you shouldn't suggest laptop which have an U in the processor series. The reason stand that the U is an indicator that CPU has been drafted for users Customer, so it's not professional, because the performance it's peaked for the target : normal users, peoples.
If you have to work, do not buy a laptop with "U" letter in cpu.

Btw, there's one other and very big thing that people often forget to take into account. Machines glitch. They glitch a lot. No matter how good your IT department is.

For example, where I currently work as an intern we have a lot of standartised reports automated. Analysts basically just need to prepare the data to fit a specific template, and then the robots can prepare all the reports for us. However, with every new update to the report templates and/or the robots there are inevitably a bunch of new bugs, including robots preparing certain reports incorrectly or refusing to prepare them at all. And sure, sooner or later the tech guys are going to fix it (until something new breaks, at least), but when push comes to shove and our deadlines are close (which they constantly are), it is up to the analysts to actually do everything by hand until the robots get fixed. And that's why, despite all the automatisation, we're still needed at the job.

I'm thinking about my job and how complex the business is and I'm not sure AI can fully replace what I do. Our business has 1000s of tables with complex relationships that are very complex in nature. Our orders table, for example,  has billions of records with information on taxing, discounts, products etc... that all relate to other objects. I'm starting to think about all the views and tables we create for reporting needs and all the complex logic and SQL that goes into creating these views and I just don't see how that can be fully automated without a human being involved. Can the AI and human work together. Sure, but the AI on its own doesn't sound like it can work. After the data has been massaged and transformed there are so many ways to interpret the results that you couldn't possibly rely on just AI for that without human intervention. I think the two will ultimately work together and nobody has to freak out about AI replacing any jobs.

I think people also confuse ‚ÄúAutomation‚Äù with ‚ÄúArtificial General intelligence‚Äù which from my understanding are two very different things. 

At a certain point if a large majority of jobs get ‚Äúautomated‚Äù and it puts a large amount of people out of work then who will be left to actually buy stuff? 

I highly doubt all those articles about ‚Äúuniversal income‚Äù Governments already tax the hell out of us. I can‚Äôt see them just giving a large amount of the population a decent amount of money every month.

I appreciate the work you've put into these tutorials; I get a strong impression that you really know what you're doing. However, the learning experience with this particular video...just didn't feel good. On the one hand, during grad a school a professor once told me that in grad school I'm learning how to learn, so I understand that there will be times when I'll just have to go out of my way to fill in the gaps when trying to learn something from someone (like an instructor) or something (like a textbook). On the other hand...it feels like there were a LOT of gaps to fill in with this video, and during the lesson I wasn't sure what I was supposed to look up to fill in those gaps. 

Maybe it's because I'm using a different version of software than what was used in the video, or maybe our applications had been configured differenlty, but I just could not create the stored procedure based off of the SQL code in the video, and it wasn't until after I had seen the code on GitHub that I finally could. Moreover, I had to figure out how to open up a new tab to modify the stored procedure because I couldn't tell how you had done it in the video, and then after that I had to figure out how to commit the changes that I had made to the stored procedure. 

After having finished the video, I did a search for the keyword 'GO' since I had to use that to create the stored procedure, and I thought, "Oh...okay. That...kinda makes sense." And then I did a search on how to create a stored procedure in SQL, and then I finally thought, "Oh! That makes sense!" It's like...everything from 'CREATE PROCEDURE' all the way up to 'GO' inclusive was one big transaction (or a collection of SQL statements that I have to be performed all together as one atomic unit). Moreover, the semi-colon ( ; ) doesn't seem to be necessary when coding in T-SQL, but explicitly typing that character out makes it clear (at least to me) where a statement or transaction is intended to terminate. 

So once again, thank you for your effort to explain these concepts. You really do seem to be very knowledgeable on the material. I'm just concerned that key details are being inadvertently omitted because they seem like second nature to you as a function of your years of experience. Take care.

ok. so immediately after creating my stored procedure, i ran into the problem of it not being in the right database even though i did everything correctly and without syntax errors. if you also have this problem, i'm writing this comment to (hopefully) help. sorry, it'll be a long read.
so! like i said my stored procedure was not in my SQL Tutorial database as intended and after some searching through my own files still nothing. i read a comment saying that someone found their stored procedure in the master database, so i checked in there and there it was! so if you haven't been able to locate your own, yours may be there. after locating it, i looked up how to move the stored procedure to the right database and the steps i followed are here with my notes in brackets:

1. Go the server in Management Studio
2. Select the database, right click on it Go to Task.
3. Select generate scripts option under Task
4. and once its started select the desired stored procedures you want to copy [for this step i chose to just open the script in a new query window so i didn't have to download a file and work more quickly, but choose the method that is best for you)


now once you have the script of the stored procedure pulled up, look to the very top at (what i guess to be) the USE statement. the database in which the stored procedure is in will be in brackets. go to the USE and change the name of the database to the one in which you want to be the location of the stored procedure. once you change the database as needed, execute the whole thing and you should be good to go! be sure to check for the location and refresh as needed to make sure everything went smoothly before moving on. please note that these steps may not be helpful if you made a typo or anything, so check your query that created the stored procedure to see where you may have an issue. i suppose in the future, for creating objects such as stored procedures and anything else that needs a location specified, placing that USE statement when you first write the query may be the best course of action. i'm still new to this so there may be better ways to do this. at any rate, i hope this helps!! :)

edit: an additional note! i learned that to specify the database location, you must use GO directly after the USE statement, otherwise you'll get an error saying that the CREATE statement must be first (not totally sure what the GO does in this case, if anyone knows please share! :) ) so when you're creating your stored procedure for the temp table, write this right before your CREATE statement: 
USE [ ]
GO

your desired database will go in the brackets of course :) then you should be good to go to continue writing your query!

edit 2: I double checked in my master database and saw i had a copy of my TEST stored procedure, so i just deleted them once i made sure i moved them to my desired database. so do with these copies as you see fit!

I was slightly struggling with it to follow along so here is the steps to actually get the same result: 
1) You write a stored procedure: drop table if exists, create table, inset into and select - finish with GO (you can also wrap the whole thing in: BEGIN (all queries) END
2) Run what you wrote (all of it)
3) Exec [store procedure name]
4) Modify - add parameter 
5) Run the whole thing again ( I mean the modify query)
6) Exec  [store procedure name] [your parameter]

To enrollees & potential enrollees: I stress having a sense of healthy urgency to complete this program. It is not a course, per say. Courses are individual modules adding up to a full specialization, program, or professional certificate; it is a number of courses rolled into a program where one should pace themselves to actually LEARN the materials & not speed rush through it just to obtain a certificate. 

However, you can still review the materials after you've finished if you rushed through it. I don't recommend this method because most ppl don't typically commit themselves 2 do that. And don't cheat. You only short or limit yourself if you don't properly leverage the program's skills & training the right way. 

Employers are generally not hiring based on your tech/hard skills alone (or at all) which can be more or less OTJ training anyway. They are hiring more so based off of your soft skills. Faking it until you're making it usually don't always apply. So build on your business acumen or portfolio after SUCCESSFULLY completing the program & let the program work FOR you not against you.

DON'T DEFEAT THE PURPOSE‚ùï ACHIEVE THE PURPOSE‚Äº

#GoogleDataAnalytics #DataAnalytics

I've used dataquest and Datacamp. I prefer dataquest because of two things.
The first is personal, I'm a reading person. I'm not able to learn following videos. 
But there is a different thing. Dataquest's career path are more cohesive. 
Datacamp has multiple skill paths and they just combine them in some bigger career path. This create the following problem: In many moments, videos do not build in previous videos. 
So, you may learn how to do something with a specific package, and then in the next set of videos, a different package is used or the re-explain a package already covered in other course.

In dataquest, as they have fewer paths, it seems that they are always buillding on top of previous courses. This is great for solidifying your knowledge.

Alex, your level of R is beginner, with all due respect. There is a noticeable bias in his speech. 

In general, because Python is more related to C and programming languages in general, it is easier for programmers. R is easier for people with no prior programming knowledge; they learn to program as long as they learn to use R. They can use R on a day-to-day basis without delving into functional programming, object-oriented programming, and so on.

The scalability issue is real. IT teams like Python best for launching products because it's their comfort zone. However, it's easier to build a dashboard or application in R. Give it a try!

I agree with the argument that there is no best, but it is necessary to reduce the bias of our point of view to make a comparison.
Simple fact is that a good programmer in either language can handle 95% of data analytics tasks easily.

Python is unquestionably more straightforward as a language in general. However, it's fundamentally a general-purpose scalar language, not a vector-data language like R or a matrix language like matlab. That fact makes the type of data manipulation and analysis that is meat and potatoes in R less convenient in Python. "Hello world" is easier in Python, but real data analysis is easier in R.  I use Python for general programming, but it's just not worth the trouble to force Python to pretend to be R for data analysis, econometrics, or statistics. Python is way, way behind in all forms of data analysis. For example, Python is only now considering basic ideas like "missing" values being different from "not a number" values, which the creators of R thought of and planned for from day 1. If I had to pick one language as "better," I might choose Python, but it's not better for data analysis, which is what's being discussed here.

Hi Alex,
How can we do a proper case in SQL?
Is there a way to do that?

And if we wanted to  lower case just the second letter of the name TOby for example, or any other name in which the second letter is uppercase we could use the following: 
*LEFT meaning only the letters starting from the LEFT, and the number 1 means only 1 letter. Basically only the first left letter. 
*LEN meaning the length of the name, so basically this will use the maximum length of the name. 
SELECT FirstName, UPPER(LEFT(FirstName,1)) + SUBSTRING(LOWER(FirstName),2,LEN(FirstName)) AS CorrectedName
FROM SQLTutorial..EmployeeErrors

For anyone following along in postgreSQL, use TEMP or TEMPORARY to create your temporary tables. Unfortunately, postgreSQL doesn't recognize the # sign in creating temp tables. 
EX:

CREATE TEMP TABLE temp_employee(
employeeid INT,
jobtitle VARCHAR(100),
salary INT
);

I have been using Datacamp for over 5 years on and off. The best way to learn is to have 3 things open at the same time ChatGPT, an IDE for SQL or Python, R (etc.) for whatever you  are learning to practice full code on the spot and trial and error, and data camp.
After each major lesson on Data Camp write the whole code on your own and use data camp to give your more context and clear example or to generate data for your small projects. This is the best way to actually retain information. The short Data camp videos may lack context or depth Chat GPT can help.
Data Camp is useful for curriculum and exposure. It provides an outline of in demand skills needed. Avoid taking course in any platform that all they do is go over a programming language from A to Z like a dictionary, you will not be able to retain and is not necessary to learn everything. Just learn the skills you need to succeed for the industry you want to be in and practice doing real life projects that interests you.

$25 a month...billed annually, which is a lot up front. If you do monthly, it's $29. If you want the "tier" with the projects, that'll be $33 a month paid annually or $49 monthly . It's not a cheap service.

I think it's important to supplement Datacamp with other resources.  Maybe some others like Coursera/Udemy for some high level theory.  Like you said, it's great for learning syntax and for beginners who need a lot of spoon feeding.  I am learning Python and SQL on this platform right now.  After a a short video, we jump into these exercises with fill-in-the-blanks without knowing  what server it is using, how to upload datasets into the server, and sometimes what the goal of a problem is.  It takes you to a screen and you just starting filling in the blanks. It doesn't reflect real life.  Datacamp is valuable for learning technical skills (and I really like their user interface), but I think newbies need additional resources.

I know I‚Äôm commenting on this a year later but you were wrong about the travel industry specifically regarding short term rentals like Airbnb and VRBO. What happened in regards to travel was people were flying less which means destination vacations like Hawaii or flying across the country were showing a major slow down. Instead, people started looking for great areas that they could drive to and at a reasonable distance. Drive to destinations like The Smoky Mountains in Tennessee, Destin Florida, and Miramar beach and Joshua Tree absolutely exploded. Owners of rentals were seeing the highest rates they‚Äôve ever been able to charge because people just wanted to get away and a lot of the travelers were using their COVID checks to pay for these vacations. That and the increase in remote work allowed people to work and also visit a place they‚Äôve never been to before. Another tip I would include is: Confidence comes with experience. While there will always some level of anxiety related to doing a job interview, you'll find its greatly reduced if you have experience in the domain, tools, and technology associated with the role. This doesn't have to be exclusively work experience. It can be hours of SQL practice or several projects using Python. Employers are looking for people that can help them get work done. And if you have a lot of work you got done, you can come in with confidence that you will be someone of value to the company. Do not neglect this part. Get in the practice on tools and tech you will use, finish projects in the domain and industry you want to work in, and shamelessly post about it somewhere! Build confidence.

2. The field may end up over the next few years becoming a hybrid of data analytics, data science, data engineering.

Hey there, enjoying the content so keep it up! Biggest thing I would add is you have only focused on the technical skills here and not the other aspects that come into data analytics. From a technical standpoint I personally do not think there is much of a difference between Mid level and Senior level, slight improvements yes but the biggest technical difference is between junior and mid level. 

However from a problem solving there is a big difference. e.g. junior analyst you produce the data which is ask of you, mid level you think more about what they are asking and find ways to add additional value or highlight opportunities you have notices. Senior level you are comfortable going back to a CEO or head of department level figure and asking is this really what you want because half the time they are not asking the question they really want solved. 

Final thing I would add is you skill of communicating the data, you may be able to produce the most accurate model but if you cannot communicate the findings it will likely be forgotten.

Meat-stuffed tomatoes with cheese on top and baked in the oven are the best! Take some tomatoes (preferably big-ish) and cut off the tops. Scoop the centre out with a spoon and fill it with grounded meat (or grounded meat mixed with rice, as I do), then cover with some grated cheese on top. Ideally, your meat should be up to around the tomato's top and the cheese somewhat over it, so everything bakes nicely and the tomato doesn't get too dry. Then stuff it into a preheated oven and cook until all looks good to eat! Will probably take around 20 minutes depending on the oven's temperature and how big the tomatoes are.

And the recipe can be adjusted however you want - take bigger tomatoes if you want to put more meat inside, or cover with a lot of cheese if that's your thing, or have a lot of small tomatoes if you're mostly in it for the veggies. Very juicy, very tasty and very easy to make!

I wish more people understood that Discussing your salary with your coworkers only helps the both of you to make sure the company doesn‚Äôt underpay you. 

Most Companies don‚Äôt want employees discussing their salaries with each other because it enables the company to pay people who are doing the same work differently. Many times newer people get paid more because it cost more to hire someone away from another company, their skills could be better, etc. 

Many people may think that if they do above average work that their salary is probably more than their peers and don‚Äôt want to share their salary to avoid jealousy or whatever other reason but most of the time companies are trying to pay you the least they can for the maximum amount of high quality work they can squeeze out of you. 

One argument I‚Äôve heard is that ‚ÄúHigh Performers‚Äù shouldn‚Äôt share their salary because the company may pay them more than their peers doing the same job and them sharing their salary could cause conflict in the workplace; maybe even make management unhappy with them. 

However, In my experience too many people think they‚Äôre ‚Äúhigh performers‚Äù when they‚Äôre not. We always tend to think the best of ourself and are more critical about other people than we are for ourselves. 

In some cases high performers do get paid more but they have to truly bring significant Value to the company. By value i mean they increase productivity, cut significant costs, or increase revenue significantly.

For those who want to copy paste....


WITH CTE_Employee as 
(SELECT FirstName, LastName, Gender, Salary
, COUNT (Gender) OVER (PARTITION BY Gender) as TotalGender
, AVG (Salary) OVER (PARTITION BY Gender) as AvgSalary
FROM [SQL Tutorial].dbo.EmployeeDemographics as emp
	join [SQL Tutorial]..EmployeeSalary as sal
		on emp.EmployeeID = sal.EmployeeID
WHERE Salary > '45000'
)

At :40 did he have some shortcut to bring up those queries? Or was that just a jump scare? I tried the shortcut from the Object Explorer and that's not what it brings up.

Example:
AVG(Salary) OVER (PARTITION BY CompanyDepartment)

First, look at the "PARTITION BY CompanyDepartment." This means to find all the possible groups in that column, CompanyDepartment. So let's say that all the possible groups are Sales Department, Marketing Department, and Engineering Department. 

Now, take a look at the "AVG(Salary)." This means that for each group (which we found above), find the AVG(Salary) for that group. For this example, this means that for the Sales Department, find the AVG(Salary) for that department. And same for the Marketing Department and Engineering Department.

This is my thought process for how to think of PARTITION BY, but everyone has their own thought process, so if your way works, then it works!

I hope this helps!

If you are like me who reached this part of the bootcamp but have nothing to practice to, try this assessment created by chatGPT.

prompt: act as a test administrator and course instructor. create an exercise to test my sql knowledge in: creating table,inserting data into table,updating table values,deletingg table values,select statements,joins,union,case statement,where,having,order by,grouup by, paratition by and aliasing.
NOTE:to use join and union, the student should be asked to create two tables first

SQL ASSESSMENT TEST

Instructions:
This test is designed to evaluate your knowledge and proficiency in SQL. You will be assessed on your ability to create tables, insert and manipulate data, write queries using various SQL statements, and apply common SQL concepts such as joins, union, case statements, where clauses, having clauses, order by clauses, group by clauses, partition by clauses, and aliasing.

There are 20 questions in this test, each question is worth 5 points. You will have 60 minutes to complete the test. Good luck!

SECTION 1: Creating and Manipulating Tables

Write a SQL query to create a table named "employees" with columns for "id" (integer), "name" (text), "age" (integer), "salary" (numeric), and "department" (text).

Write a SQL query to insert the following data into the "employees" table created in question 1:
id=1, name="John", age=35, salary=55000, department="Sales"
id=2, name="Jane", age=27, salary=45000, department="Marketing"
id=3, name="Tom", age=45, salary=70000, department="IT"
id=4, name="Alice", age=32, salary=60000, department="HR"
id=5, name="Bob", age=29, salary=50000, department="Sales"
id=6, name="Sarah", age=31, salary=65000, department="IT"
id=7, name="David", age=28, salary=50000, department="Marketing"
id=8, name="Karen", age=40, salary=75000, department="Sales"
id=9, name="Michael", age=36, salary=60000, department="IT"
id=10, name="Emily", age=24, salary=40000, department="HR"
id=11, name="Kevin", age=33, salary=58000, department="Sales"
id=12, name="Michelle", age=29, salary=48000, department="Marketing"
id=13, name="Steven", age=42, salary=72000, department="IT"
id=14, name="Christine", age=37, salary=67000, department="Sales"
id=15, name="Rachel", age=26, salary=45000, department="Marketing"
id=16, name="Alex", age=39, salary=68000, department="IT"
id=17, name="Andrew", age=31, salary=55000, department="Sales"
id=18, name="Katie", age=30, salary=52000, department="Marketing"
id=19, name="Brian", age=43, salary=78000, department="IT"
id=20, name="Lisa", age=34, salary=61000, department="Sales"

Write a SQL query to update the salary of employee with id=2 to 48000.

Write a SQL query to delete the employee with id=5 from the "employees" table.


SECTION 2: Writing SELECT Queries
5. Write a SQL query to retrieve the names and ages of all employees in the "employees" table.

Write a SQL query to retrieve the names and salaries of all employees in the "Sales" department.

Write a SQL query to retrieve the names, ages, and departments of all employees who are older than 30.

Write a SQL query to retrieve the names and salaries of employees whose salary is greater than 55000, ordered by salary in descending order.


SECTION 3: Using Joins, Union, and Case Statements

Write a SQL query to create a table named "departments" with columns for "department_id" (integer) and "department_name" (text).

Write a SQL query to insert the following data into the "departments" table created in question 9:
department_id=1, department_name="Sales"
department_id=2, department_name="Marketing"
department_id=3, department_name="IT"
department_id=4, department_name="HR"

Write a SQL query to retrieve the names and departments of all employees in the "employees" table, including those who have no department assigned.

Write a SQL query to retrieve the names and departments of all employees in the "employees" table, but only for those employees who have a department assigned.

Write a SQL query to retrieve the names and departments of all employees in the "employees" table, including those who have no department assigned, and order the results by department name in ascending order.

Write a SQL query to retrieve the names and salaries of all employees in the "Sales" department, as well as the names and salaries of all employees in the "Marketing" department, and order the results by department name in ascending order.

Write a SQL query to retrieve the names and salaries of all employees in the "Sales" department, as well as the names and salaries of all employees in the "Marketing" department, and combine the results using a UNION operator.

Write a SQL query to retrieve the names and salaries of all employees in the "Sales" department, as well as the names and salaries of all employees in the "Marketing" department, and combine the results using a UNION ALL operator.

Write a SQL query to retrieve the names and salaries of all employees, but display their salary as "High" if it is greater than 60000, "Medium" if it is between 40000 and 60000, and "Low" if it is less than 40000.

See, Partition by would have been REALLY great to know when I was trying to get a "total sum" of a given inventory item that was broken down by lots in a location. For example. Item 123 could have lot a, lot b and lot c in 1 location. there might be 2 in one lot, 3 in another and 5 in another.  My solution was to subquery the "Sum all items in a location" then "Inner join" that sum and join on the Item Location (as that will always be unique)... so instead of having a really large query, this partition by would have shrunk the query down to an easy to read "Look here is the items, their locations and total sum of all the lots in each location.. 

Well.. better late than never.

I think hiring staff at companies would be better off if they saw one particular scene from the movie "A Beautiful Mind". It was about famous Mathematician John Nash.

There was a scene where Nash and his college buddies were at a bar and there were several women. But there was 1 blonde lady there that they all were drooling over. Nash pointed out that if they ALL went for her they would all lose. And then if they followed that up by going after her friends they would give them the cold shoulder for being the "second option". But if they sacrificed getting "the best option" to get the "good enough option" they would all have an equal chance at going home with a woman.

The moral of the story is this: bring your expectations down to reality. Maybe don't shoot for the top 5 or 10%. Try shooting for the top 35%? If necessary, get more people to look over your online application submissions in order to properly assess what talent you have. Plus, corporate America already has a pretty bad stink of treating the people behind the applications (and their employees) as numbers rather than people.

And if corpo america doesn't want that...maybe just hire whoever they can find locally. Have your employees do prebono work to find your applicants at local universities. Pester the students to apply. Go back to printing ads in the paper or something like that.

Maybe a bit nit-picky on my part, but it drives me CRAZY when recruiters/hiring managers cannot post the job ad properly.  Big things are: spelling mistakes on basic words ("Bachalors"), inconsistent details (hiring for junior, yet listing mid-senior) and above all, NOT knowing what a Data Analyst does.

They hold applicants to a very high standard, yet cannot bother to proof-read their own job ad.  It drives me absolutely bonkers!

I had heard through the grape vine that a lot of former military people with these credentials didn't realize how much they could command and were routinely underpaid. Can you tell me if these traits/personality qualities make Data Analyst a good or bad match? For those interested, this is theoretical mumbo jumbo of MBTI's INFJ personality type. IEI and Te-PolR are in reference to me:

IEI: I make lots of little factual errors, don't focus on the little details unless absolutely forced to. I don't care about doing things "the best way" unless it's something I really care about. If it's something I really care about, I will slave over it (not Te-polr related, just explaining), and be meticulous and obsessive and perfectionist. If it's something I don't care about, I will literally do a way that takes longer and wastes time and doesn't do the job as well just for the sake of not having to focus on it. I am *so* indifferent to "optimization" (that's a Te buzzword).

Te-PoLR have trouble dealing with things in a detached and rational manner. They have trouble focusing on work and tend to have trouble doing things the way things are "supposed" to be done, often doing things in a way that is most emotionally stimulating which can be perceived as wasteful of time or resources. They fear that they won't meet objective expectations or that they will be forced to do so.

Te-polr have problems trusting information they're given. They are unlikely to trust unreliable sources of information and make a determination based on anything but personal experience or vision. I've found that often IEI like to have some (what they feel to be reliable) reference material which they will consult when doing something, but often have problems doing research outside of that. They're often quite skeptical of reasonable reliable sources of information that some people find ok. They need someone to explain it to them or someone to do it and prove it in front of them, then they will have some trust of that information.

In addition to the Excel skills mentioned in the video, I recommend becoming familiar with Power Query in Excel as well.  
I work in an environment where I don't have access to a DBMS or Python, so I've been doing all of my analysis by writing SQL connections in Excel and then using Power Query for cleaning, transforming, and EDA (or pushing these into the SQL queries whenever possible).  
It's very intuitive if you already understand SQL and Pandas, and you can do some pretty useful analysis with it.

Thanks for your videos, Alex.  I just finished the Google Data Analytics Professional certificate on Coursera.  It was a good mix of data concepts and hands-on with SQL (Google BigQuery), Tableau and R.  It involves videos, reading, quizzes and hands-on projects.  The fact that it is structured helped me stay on track.  I spent 3 hours per day at an easy pace.  The only thing to note is that you learn basic R instead of Python.  A little note for those taking the course:  the dataset for global CO2 emissions by year lacks data for Germany and Russia prior to 1994.  The Tableau graph  showed a discontinuity and I had to be a detective and find the issue.

I think I have what is opposite of imposter syndrome which is inferior complexity. I could be wrong as to the exact definition, but I consistently feel that I may never be good enough to get myself a good job. I tend to perceive myself as inferior to many people. I developed this when I was in the military. I went in at an older age (34) and everyone my age was either an officer or my superior. I began to suffer from depression and anxiety from the social isolation and feelings of loneliness and feelings of not being good enough or far enough in life.  Now having been three year's since I graduated with a master's degree in exercise science, I have yet to work a job that takes any sort of skill. Most the the jobs I have had the past three years are manual labor and retail jobs requiring nothing more than a high-school diploma. I am positive this is contributing to my worsening depression and anxiety along with inferior complexity. I now plan to begin an online master's program in analytics or AI and machine learning, I may end up doing both. I am hoping that by the time I graduate which will be around the age of 47 and having no domain experience, I can land my first data analyst job. I would hope to inspire other people who are in their mid 40s or older that it can be done even if you have worked none other than low-wage, low-skilled jobs. Besides my four years in the military, the most I have made in one year is around 19k. The day I do land a good job, I'll make sure to include some eggplant in my dinner! I thought I'd mention this. Things have been so bad as far as finding a job the past three years, that back in 2018 I filled out an application and sent a resume to work at McDonald's as a crew member! I never heard back! I doubt they have any thing related to eggplant on their menu. They could come up with the McEggplant burger or salad!

Did you try the "escabeche" eggplant?

‚ÄúEscabeche‚Äù Eggplant
Ingredients
 
3 large eggplants (about 2.2 lb)
3 tablespoons Himalayan pink salt (or regular granny salt)
2 cups of white vinegar
1 cup of water
1 cup of Olive oil
1/2 teaspoon of black pepper
1/2 tablespoon of Paprika
1/2 tablespoon of chili flakes
1/2 tablespoon of oregano
2 bay leaves
1 cup of sunflower oil, it may be more or less


Marinated "Escabeche" Eggplant by Sigrilina -- This is a great way to preserve eggplants and to infuse them with flavor.
Preparation
Step 1 Peel the eggplant and cut in 3/8 inch slices.
Step 2 Put the eggplant in a bowl and mix thoroughly with the Himalayan pink salt. Let it rest for 30 minutes.
Step 3 In a pot mix the vinegar with the water, set aside.
Step 4 Rinse the eggplant slices.
Step 5 Cook the eggplant in the vinegar-water mixture for 2 or 3 minutes or until they have acquired the hardness of your liking. Check on them often as they tend to be very hard and then to soft quite quickly.
Step 6 Drain the eggplant and set aside.
Step 7 In a small bowl mix the olive oil with the spices and the bay leaves.
Step 8 In a sterilized jar, alternate eggplant and the oil mixture. Remember to put the bay leaves in between.
Step 9 When you are done, cover the rest of the jar with sunflower oil until the eggplants are fully covered.
Step 10 Before consumption let rest for at least one week in the refrigerator so the eggplants are really infused with the flavor.
Step 11 Store in the refrigerator for up to 3 weeks.

source: https://sigrilina.com/marinated-escabeche-eggplant/

Interesting facts about Cabbage

1. Ancient roots. Cabbage has been cultivated for longer than almost any other vegetable on record. To be precise, more than 6,000 years! It originated in Shensi Province, China, sometime around 4,000 B.C.

2. Elixir for Baldness. In ancient China (roughly 1000 B.C.) scrolls touted cabbage as a magic cure-all for bald men. It‚Äôs hard to say if there‚Äôs any truth in this claim, but no one can deny cabbage is chock full of nutrients that promote good health.

3. Vitamin C Galore. Cabbage contains a high concentration of Vitamin C. That means it cuts out toxins in your body, preventing skin disease, arthritis, and rheumatism. Go for red cabbage when you have Vitamin C in mind. It contains double the content of regular green cabbage.

Why do you always say negative about these careers?

Please tell something positive which can motivate people like me who are transiting towards data science from electrical engineering.

this experience can be summed up as: biggest dumpster fire

normally, wasn't an issue. data jobs were the fastest growing jobs of 2015-2020 until the market took a huge nose dive. now you have people with senior level experience applying to junior level jobs as well as PhDs with who knows what kind of experience. Lots of people are not only graduating and applying to these roles, but a lot of analysts lost their jobs. 

So now data jobs are in a huge predicament. If the market doesn't recoil back to equilibrium, companies are going to want even MORE experience than what they already want! I'm seeing 3 years experience needed, and some companies want 5! For entry! 

No...I'm not salty about it...

Hello Alex,

I hope you are doing well. Let me start by saying first "jalape√±os." I know this is one of your older videos, but it is so impactful. Thank you for taking the time to share your story with us. 

I have always loved analyzing data. I retired from the Marine Corps a few years back and have been trying to find my place in a new career. I naturally look toward operations management; it is my comfort zone. I held a position as a Business Analyst as my first role right out of the service and loved the work, but I felt something was missing. I always used data to help me make decisions, but I didn't have the necessary KSAs to take me to the next level, so I went back into operations management. 

Based on your recommendations in some other videos, I started taking classes on Coursera. While I have not made it to where I want to be yet, I know I will make it there.

I will touch bases with you in the future with an update once I make it; but, I will say this up front:

Thank you for being a part of my success. 

-Andre

Saying not to lie on a resume, or not too grossly exaggerate, is absurd, when the rules of the game as established by employers themselves, require that you lie. In case anyone hasn't noticed, entry level jobs no longer exist. By that I mean every job listed as entry-level now requires 2 + years of experience. In effect, what this means is what I previously said, entry level jobs no longer exist. Thus, unless you fabricate something very cleverly, or exaggerated to the ultimate degree, how does one without the requisite experience gain employment? Employers have no right to expect a hundred percent veracity from prospective employees when the rules of the game as established by the employers themselves demand that you not be truthful in order to gain employment. Bottom line is, if you tell people to lie to you, don't be surprised or angered when they do.

That is what happens when you have multiple people applying for the same position, so I can get where they are coming from, but it means as an employee you do what you have to do to get noticed. 

I have been stuck in a career change due to it being a career change and me lacking experience even though I have an advanced degree in the topic. You should lie on your CV (UK) = at the end of the day, when someone is finally given the job - depending what it is but a lot of times what they want you to say at an interview can be completely different to what they want you to do on the job. For example, on the interview the employer would say things like "we are here for you when you have tough family matters" "safety is everything" "respect is everything" "equality is everything" etc etc you get the point. You get the job, arrive at the place, explain to everyone you're new and within minutes a hand ful of those employees have gone against what you was told on the interview/application. Apprentices for example - some of them go through a tough process to get the apprentice, and when they are on the job, they are treat like piece of shit on a shoe, being victimised by "initiation pranks" and just being the mental and physical punch bag for all the other workers. So why can't we lie on CVs when most advertised jobs are also based off lies? What's worse than your colleagues treating you like a retarded puppy at your new job? your actual bosses and supervisors getting in on the joke too!.

So for those reasons - I would say "go ahead" to anyone wanting to put on the odd lie on their CV.. unless it's for a career sort of job like becoming a doctor, cop etc..because then you are completely screwed. But applying for a job at some factory or whatever..go ahead and lie to get you that place.. chances are.. most did in the first place.

I say lie on your resume.

Unfortunately hiring managers love to play these gatekeeper roles, and they do a fantastic job at it. In fact, they do such a good job at it that the United States, who used to be the epicenter of manufactured goods, is now reduced to a ‚Äúconsumer‚Äôs market‚Äù with its World Reserve status on the rocks. See, lying is something they had to do themselves to get where they are today...but then those same people expect their prospects to be honest??

As far as reputation goes, if they try to ruin your reputation, if anything it sheds a light on their character that they don‚Äôt want shining on them, and it may even introduce lawsuits. Personally, in the industry I represent (IT), I haven‚Äôt heard of an employee getting ousted for lying on a resume, and they have no business doing so. The best case scenario of just getting fired is actually the common method of handling a liar (at least in the industry I‚Äôm in).

Now when it comes to something where human lives are involved such as driving a plane or surgeries, I agree you shouldn‚Äôt lie during those times. Any other case, I say go for it. Once again, they can lie to you in your face, and yet they expect honesty from you?? They can lie to you about compensation, actual responsibilities, your benefits, your hours, and potential for career advancement within the organization. They can even lie to you about your longevity within that organization. I‚Äôve seen personal horror stories where people get let go after sinking years into a particular company simply because their services were ‚Äúno longer needed‚Äù. No justification. No closure. I‚Äôve even seen people complete a project, and get laid off immediately after without disclosing that the position was temporary.

TL;DR Lie. They get to lie to you (and they often will), so it‚Äôs only fair if you do the same.

What we refuse to accept is the reality, that Data science, analysis and engineering were not meant to be standalone roles in most organisations. You are to use Data related jobs as complementary skillsets like Excel, Word, PowerPoint and other programs to your other main job description. 
You can be a medical professional and data analyst with medical data. As an Educator, data science, analysis etc complement student data processing and visualization. 
HR personnel needs the Data science/analysis skillset as a complement to the organisational toolkit, not stand alone. 
Else you will find yourself in and out of your primary job functions as a Data analyst.

in my exp, the roles are swapped. My life as a data analyst had much more expectations, less resources / software, and required much more business exp. My life as a business analyst required more technical skills, and was more closely tied to leadership. I spent 7 years more aligned as a DA, and 3 years as a BA and it was much much harder as a DA.
Business analysts receive more salary than data analysts

Great breakdown, but I‚Äôd like to add that Business Analysts don‚Äôt always come from business or MBA backgrounds. Many enter the field through certifications and practical experience, especially in data-focused roles. Certifications like CBAP, PMI-PBA, or even structured learning paths such as the Business Analyst Track from 365 Data Science can equip professionals with the right skills. In today‚Äôs job market, hands-on skills in SQL, Excel, BI tools, and real-world problem-solving often outweigh traditional degrees.

Data Analyst vs Business Analyst | Which Is Right For You?

For you who are googling for this and get hinged on the salary, it's good to remember that these are mostly US salary levels. For example, in Switzerland, a Business Analyst & Data Analyst make the same salary from junior through to mid, but in senior the Business Analyst is actually earning more. So, check out stuff like that depending on where you live, because this has a lot to do with demand and supply. Some countries have more business analysts and some more data analysts, though at the end of the day, these are in demand in most countries and you'll probably make a really good earning.

Our DA's are not allowed to interact with anyone lol we put them in a cell with a computer, sql, and water. The BA's, project managers, and senior directors go to them and say get me XYZ from SQL database. They send the raw data that is desperate converted to M excel, and that's it. Our DA don't know how the data correlates to the departments job because they get data orders from many departments all over the country! So the BA reads the data, interprets the data, format the data, and create business solutions based on that data for their team. Each team usually has one BA, while our DAs is an entire department by themselves. This is how Centene, number 48 company on the fortune 500 list, has things set up. I am currently a BA and I'm planning to transfer to DA in about 3-4 years.  I have an AA in business administration and will have a BA in technology management in 2 years. My certifications include business operations management, excel, and Data Analytics. Idk why I made this long ass comment lol

Alex, great video.  Just want to add some context to Coursera's UC Davis Data Visualization With Tableau recommendation.  This is a great course to learn the fundamentals of data visualization, and what you learn will help you with whatever software you choose to utilize.  In the course, you will learn the basics of how to use Tableau, but this is not an in-depth how to do everything in Tableau.  Many students come into the course with that misperception and miss the platform-agnostic knowledge of visualizing data.  Again, great video, and thanks for sharing your journey.

My thinking:
1. Learn programming: Python, R, SAS
2. Learn spreadsheets: Excel, Google Sheets
3. Learn visualization: Tableau, Power BI
4. Learn to query: SQL
5. Learn Git and GitHub (putting projects there will help build portfolio)

A note to all: don't pay full price for Udemy courses. Wait until they go on sale, then buy a couple/few to hold you over until the next sale. If you are low income, Coursera offers financial aid. Have to answer 3 essay questions and wait 15 days to know whether approved or not. Have to apply for each course. Get on mailing lists of various learning platforms. Datacamp recently had 3 days free. Also, the first module of most courses is always free. Check out bundle packages on TNW (deals . thenextweb . com I think.) They even have "pay what you want".

I disagree on your opinion on lettering joins. The reason being is that if my join list gets to be 5, 6, 7 tables then I have an idea of where the table is in the join list as long as I adhere to that alphabetic order. So if I see my column is in table D or E then I can quickly look down the list to find that table. The alias does not readily tell you what the table's full name and path are. What if you have similarly named tables in more than one schema? What if you are not familiar with these tables. If I letter them I can quickly figure out where in my join I put the table. I've also run into enough issues where too many of the tables are named almost identically.  I also think that putting too many letters in your alias also defeats the purpose of aliases. Aliases are there to clean up the code and shorten the column names.
I can see renaming later after you've developed it, but when trying to code all of this it clears confusion as to where the join is.

Just a small tip, Aliases can't be used as a filter condition in the WHERE clause. Ex: let's say you merge first_name and last_name and name the column as full_name, you cant go like, WHERE full_name like '%A' (full_name starting with A),   IT WONT WORK. but, it works with Order By. Hope it helps.   P:S Experience based on MYSQL only, not sure about others.

From Chat GPT: 
WHERE Clause
Purpose:

The WHERE clause is used to filter rows before any groupings are made. It filters records based on specified conditions.
Usage: Applied to individual rows in a table.
It cannot be used with aggregate functions (like SUM(), COUNT(), AVG(), etc.).
When to Use: Use the WHERE clause to filter records before aggregation or grouping.

Example:
SELECT * FROM Employees
WHERE Salary > 50000;

HAVING Clause
Purpose: The HAVING clause is used to filter groups after the GROUP BY clause has been applied. It filters records based on aggregate conditions.
Usage: Applied to groups of rows created by the GROUP BY clause.
Can be used with aggregate functions.
When to Use: Use the HAVING clause to filter aggregated data or groups of data.

Example:
SELECT DepartmentID, COUNT(*) AS EmployeeCount
FROM Employees
GROUP BY DepartmentID
HAVING COUNT(*) > 10;

Key Differences
Order of Execution:
WHERE: Filters rows before grouping and aggregation.
HAVING: Filters groups after grouping and aggregation.
Scope:
WHERE: Filters individual rows.
HAVING: Filters aggregated data (groups of rows).
Aggregate Functions:
WHERE: Cannot be used with aggregate functions.
HAVING: Can be used with aggregate functions.

Combined Use of WHERE and HAVING
In a single query, both WHERE and HAVING clauses can be used together to filter data at different stages of the query:
Filter rows before aggregation with WHERE.
Filter groups after aggregation with HAVING.

Example:
SELECT DepartmentID, AVG(Salary) AS AvgSalary
FROM Employees
WHERE JobTitle = 'Engineer'
GROUP BY DepartmentID
HAVING AVG(Salary) > 70000;

In case anyone is wondering how to remove the extra zeros in the SalaryAfterRaise column, this will get it done :)

SELECT FirstName, LastName, JobTitle, Salary,
CAST(CASE
	WHEN JobTitle = 'Salesman' THEN Salary + (Salary * .10)
	WHEN JobTitle = 'Accountant' THEN Salary + (Salary * .05)
	WHEN JobTitle = 'HR' THEN Salary + (Salary * .000001)
	ELSE Salary + (Salary * .03)
END AS DECIMAL(18, 2)) AS SalaryAfterRaise
FROM EmployeeDemographics
JOIN EmployeeSalary
	ON EmployeeDemographics.EmployeeID = EmployeeSalary.EmployeeID

Quick heads-up: in the example where we calculate the average salary of Salesmen, the INNER JOIN you use:

SELECT JobTitle, AVG(Salary)  
FROM EmployeeDemographics  
INNER JOIN EmployeeSalary  
  ON EmployeeDemographics.EmployeeID = EmployeeSalary.EmployeeID  
WHERE JobTitle = 'Salesman'  
GROUP BY JobTitle

gives 52000 but excludes this row due to a NULL ID:

(NULL, 'Salesman', 43000)

The accurate avg is 49750, which we get if we query EmployeeSalary directly. Just wanted to share for clarity ‚Äî still loving the series! üôè

select *

UNION 
select *

right join parks_and_recreation.employee_demographics
on employee_demographics.employee_id = employee_salary.employee_id;

Not sure if anyone is still active on these but when I try to use a SELECT* FROM with a WHERE query, it doubles all my values. On the original table all values are single but it returns doubles when I search and I‚Äôm not sure why? Appreciate any help! üëèüèº

IN operator is a shorthand for multiple OR Statements.¬†

In the example Alex writes,
SELECT * FROM EmployeeDemographics WHERE FirstName = ‚ÄúJim‚Äù AND FirstName=‚ÄúMichael‚Äù; then explains we can use IN instead of multiple AND Operators.

In above mentioned query, we are looking for someone with both Jim and Michael as their firstname.

Instead, we are looking for rows where FirstName is either Jim or Michael.

We can achieve this by simply using OR operator instead of AND operator.

SELECT * FROM EmployeeDemographics WHERE FirstName = ‚ÄúJim‚Äù OR FirstName=‚ÄúMichael‚Äù;

Rather than writing multiple OR operator like above, we can use IN.
SELECT * FROM EmployeeDemographics WHERE FirstName IN (‚ÄúJim‚Äù , ‚ÄúMichael‚Äù)

Ok so here's my official mildly researched take: First of all you are probably looking at a different source than what she looked at. This is the 2019 Robert Half Accounting and Finance Salary guide. it forecasts salaries for 2019. The Job you are looking at seems to be specifically for Data Analysts in Corporate Accounting. Robert Half has other salary guides such as the Technology Salary guide. I think She probably looked at the tech guide for 2020. I saw your comment saying it doesn't look like the 2020 version is out yet, but it was definitely out at the time this video was created. I found an article from August 2019 discussing the release of the 2020 Guides. According to the Technology guide, In the tech industry A "Data Analyst/Report Writer" Makes $84,750 at the 25th percentile and $100,250 at the 50th percentile (which should be at least approximately the median, I think). These sound a lot like her numbers, she may have taken the 25th percentile and reported it as an entry level salary statistic, which while not entirely honest, is probably not too far off for this particular set of jobs since your entry levels are generally going to be the ones around that 25th percentile mark (i think). Now I'm still not confident we should take the rest at face value. first of all I don't know what proportion of Data Analyst jobs fit into "Tech" as opposed to other fields like finance. second, Robert Half is an HR consulting Firm. Their numbers are based on their own placement, and I'm sure that could skew the data, I just don't know how. Also worth considering that She seems to have a very specific idea in her head when she talks about data analysts, different than what most people might think based on job titles. She clearly thinks a lot of "Data Analyst" jobs are Not real Data Analysts despite being labeled as such. Maybe this is misleading on her part, but she seems to bring it up constantly so idk. for example: I've seen your video about becoming a Data Analyst with no experience. Based on the way you describe your first data job making 47k I'd imagine she'd say that's more of a "Data Reporting Analyst" type job, which she frequently distinguishes from "Data Analyst" when she talks about Salaries (not to mention the fact that you got the job seemingly without a particularly relevant degree. I don't think you said, but I imagined something like Psychology or Social Work based on your first two jobs. She usually talks about Math degrees as common for data analyst). And personally, as an aspiring Data Analyst and Aspiring Data Scientist who has spent time around echo chambers like the r/datascience subreddit, I probably Wouldn't think "Data Analyst" when I hear that job description. When I think data analyst I expect more statistical tools being involved. For example I'm Working thru a fairly popular textbook called "Introduction to Statistical Learning with R" which covers the basics of applied statistical techniques like Regression and Support Vector Machines. I've been under the impression that This is the kind of stuff associated with the term Data Analyst (Along with data queries, and cleaning and stuff)

84k did sound high to me. but ~40k also sounds low to me. When I did job searches in my area (which is a city) I saw a lot of entry level stuff from like 55-75k. Entry level stuff past that was usually labeled "entry level data scientist" or something like that. Also, I might be wrong but it seems like higher salaries would make sense based on the kinds of degrees these jobs seem to ask for. I almost always see them asking for at least a bachelors in a "Quantitative field" which usually includes Math/Stat, Physics, Chemistry, Economics, Computer Science, or engineering. And I could be terribly mistaken as a student with no work experience but I was under the impression those degrees had a tendency to command higher salaries (especially Compsci and Enee). that's what I always hear at least. And I also sometimes see that a masters degree is preferred. I certainly hope people aren't taking on loans for a masters degree to make just 40k. But idk, maybe I've been Na√Øve and I have a rude awakening coming up after graduation.
45k is correct, this is where i am as an entry lvl analyst and we doing just sql server and excel work.
So while I definitely don't agree the numbers are that high, I did find that on Robert Half's 2020 Technology Salary guide, Data Analyst/Report writer did have the numbers she was stating.

A big caution with a lot of the resume templates in this video is they all have some form of columns in how they're formatted. While they may look great to a recruiter or hiring manager once you get an interview, most job applications are going to be submitted online and uploaded to an applicant tracking system (ATS). For those that utilize uploading an electronic document (Word or PDF), the ATS is going to have a hard time distinguishing different areas in columns. This may result in have to clean up or simply enter manually all the information the ATS is looking for like contact information, skills and work experience.

I slightly disagree with the skill bar way of showing how proficient one is. I saw a video from Joshua Fluke where he argues that different people use different parameters to evaluate their skills. So what does a 75% filled bar mean? How different is it from a 80% filled one? How do you quantify this? Also, perhaps employers could look at a non-100% filled bar and say: "if he is not even secure about his skill set, why should we hire them?" or they might not see a 75% filled bar as enough, even though your intention was to show you have a good grasp, but still has some room to improve, for example. I don't know, just felt like noting this because I like the concept and how it looks in the resume, but I think the disadvantages of the interpretation behind it outweigh the advantages.

According to on the resume expert, we are supposed to have three resumes for three different purpose. 1. For job boards: Resumes are selected by recruiters with help of ATS, scanners which uses frequency of keywords to select about top 'x' (i.e. 25) resumes. This means a resume with more keywords with high frequencies has higher probability to be one of those 'x' resumes. That means it could be 4 pages long.  2. For human: When recruiters or HR contacts you, send them a one page resume but very easy to read and follow. 3. For job interview: Take a single page resume, but designed as a marketing material as presentation with key achievements. I would appreciate your comments on them.

I think you hit the nail on the head with the differences. The great thing about small companies that I enjoy is exactly what you said - the opportunity to learn multiple skills that you are less likely to get to know in a big company.

I currently work at a small company as a Data Analyst/QA for an out of the box EDI Processing system.

While my predominate role is data analysis/QA, I've seen myself wearing a few hats.
My first year, I was doing general support as well for the department, along with data analysis and QA.
My second year, I'm seeing myself doing internal/test case development and more escalated support as it was recently established I would no longer do general support tickets and only take stuff on occasion.

I personally like wearing a lot of hats as it helps me grow, but I'd like to work at a big company as well.

Love it!  I worked at a medium-ish company which had been bought out by a larger company out of the country, but they werent very involved in the daily business yet when i was there. How and when did you learn your minimum ti even get the first good IT job? I get the impression that you study IT stuff in college or maybe hi school.

Wait...so, you just jumped over from doing unskilled labor to doing data analysis for them? This was glossed over too quickly, as it reveals a huge truth about getting a job. It's more about WHO you know than WHAT you know.

I assume your data analysis skills at the time were less than one would expect for an entry-level person to normally get hired with, but you were able to break into the data analysis field because they already knew and liked you. And after that, having some actual data analysis work on your resume gave you a huge leg-up in applying to other jobs via more traditional methods.

I'm just not convinced the data analysis field is all that good of an opportunity for most people. It seems most data analysts either transition into the role in their current job, or go through an internship as they're wrapping up college. Meanwhile people like me trying to start a new career are a dime a dozen; people with just the basic skills and certifications, being ignored by potential employers, and drowning in a sea of competition.

Whenever an entry-level data analyst job opens up online, within mere hours there are hundreds of applications already submitted. It seems rather hopeless, unless one happens to have a connection already with the company. :/

Very similar to a path I'm attempting to achieve! I graduated with a master's degree in exercise science in 2017. Yes, a boneheaded move on my part. Why? Exercise science is considered a useless degree by many and I'm probably one of many that are living proof. I made 16k in 2018, and a whopping 18k in 2019!  I've had had seven jobs the past three years, with five of them paying at or near minimum wage. Another job was personal training. I could not sell my way out of a paper bag to make that gig work. I also had a part time teaching job at a community college but was not selected for rehire the following year. Now, I have been self-teaching myself the skills needed to get into data science for the past year. My goal is to gain an entry level data analyst job so I can build my skills more and put myself through college again to pursue a quantitative degree.  Gaining an entry level data analyst job where I make even 40k would be like winning the lottery! Earning 100k, I might probably feel like I died and went to heaven. Why? I will be able to pay off my 100k student loan debt and start living life!
